ud7.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud7.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud7.1:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ lakuṇḍakabhaddiyaṃ anekapariyāyena dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
ud7.1:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring Venerable Bhaddiya the Dwarf in many ways with a Dhamma talk.

ud7.1:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato lakuṇḍakabhaddiyassa āyasmatā sāriputtena anekapariyāyena dhammiyā kathāya sandassiyamānassa samādapiyamānassa samuttejiyamānassa sampahaṃsiyamānassa anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimucci.
ud7.1:2.1.eng: Then after being taught like this Bhaddiya’s mind was freed from defilements by not grasping.

ud7.1:3.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ lakuṇḍakabhaddiyaṃ āyasmatā sāriputtena anekapariyāyena dhammiyā kathāya sandassiyamānaṃ samādapiyamānaṃ samuttejiyamānaṃ sampahaṃsiyamānaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttaṃ.
ud7.1:3.1.eng: The Buddha saw what had happened.

ud7.1:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud7.1:4.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud7.1:5.3.eng: Freed like this, he has crossed the flood

ud7.1:5.4.eng: not crossed before, so as to not be reborn.”

ud7.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
ud7.10:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

ud7.10:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rañño utenassa uyyānagatassa antepuraṃ daḍḍhaṃ hoti, pañca ca itthisatāni kālaṅkatāni honti sāmāvatīpamukhāni.
ud7.10:1.3.eng: Now at that time, while King Udena was visiting a park, his royal compound burned down. Five hundred women died, with Queen Sāmāvatī at their head.

ud7.10:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kosambiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃsu.
ud7.10:2.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Kosambī for alms.

ud7.10:2.2.pli: Kosambiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
ud7.10:2.2.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him had happened. They asked the Buddha,

ud7.10:2.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:

ud7.10:2.4.pli: “idha, bhante, rañño utenassa uyyānagatassa antepuraṃ daḍḍhaṃ, pañca ca itthisatāni kālaṅkatāni sāmāvatīpamukhāni.

ud7.10:2.5.pli: Tāsaṃ, bhante, upāsikānaṃ kā gati ko abhisamparāyo”ti?
ud7.10:2.5.eng: “Sir, where have those laywomen been reborn in the next life?”

ud7.10:3.1.pli: “Santettha, bhikkhave, upāsikāyo sotāpannā, santi sakadāgāminiyo, santi anāgāminiyo.
ud7.10:3.1.eng: “Among those laywomen there were stream-enterers, once-returners, and non-returners.

ud7.10:3.2.pli: Sabbā tā, bhikkhave, upāsikāyo anipphalā kālaṅkatā”ti.
ud7.10:3.2.eng: None of those laywomen died without some fruit of the practice.”

ud7.10:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud7.10:4.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud7.10:5.1.eng: “The world is caught up in delusion,

ud7.10:5.2.eng: but is looked on as making sense.

ud7.10:5.3.eng: The fool caught up in attachment

ud7.10:5.6.eng: but for one who sees, there is nothing.”

ud7.2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud7.2:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud7.2:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ lakuṇḍakabhaddiyaṃ sekhaṃ maññamāno bhiyyoso mattāya anekapariyāyena dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
ud7.2:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring Venerable Bhaddiya the Dwarf in even more ways with a Dhamma talk, thinking that he was still a trainee.

ud7.2:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ āyasmantaṃ lakuṇḍakabhaddiyaṃ sekhaṃ maññamānaṃ bhiyyoso mattāya anekapariyāyena dhammiyā kathāya sandassentaṃ samādapentaṃ samuttejentaṃ sampahaṃsentaṃ.
ud7.2:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw what was happening.

ud7.2:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud7.2:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud7.2:4.1.eng: “They’ve cut the cycle, gone to the wishless;

ud7.2:4.2.eng: the streams are dried, they flow no more.

ud7.2:4.3.eng: Cut, the cycle no longer spins.

ud7.2:4.4.eng: Just this is the end of suffering.”

ud7.3:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud7.3:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud7.3:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sāvatthiyā manussā yebhuyyena kāmesu ativelaṃ sattā (…) rattā giddhā gathitā mucchitā ajjhosannā sammattakajātā kāmesu viharanti.
ud7.3:1.3.eng: Now at that time most of the people in Sāvatthī overly clung to sensual pleasures. Lustful, greedy, tied, infatuated, they lived completely addicted to sensual pleasures.

ud7.3:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃsu.
ud7.3:2.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

ud7.3:2.2.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
ud7.3:2.2.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.

ud7.3:2.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:

ud7.3:2.4.pli: “idha, bhante, sāvatthiyā manussā yebhuyyena kāmesu ativelaṃ sattā rattā giddhā gathitā mucchitā ajjhosannā sammattakajātā kāmesu viharantī”ti.

ud7.3:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud7.3:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud7.3:4.1.eng: “Clinging to sensual pleasures, <j>to the chains of the senses,

ud7.3:4.2.eng: blind to the faults of the fetters,

ud7.3:4.3.eng: clinging to the chain of the fetters,

ud7.3:4.4.eng: they’ll never cross the flood so vast.”

ud7.4:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud7.4:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud7.4:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sāvatthiyā manussā yebhuyyena kāmesu sattā (…) rattā giddhā gathitā mucchitā ajjhosannā andhīkatā sammattakajātā kāmesu viharanti.
ud7.4:1.3.eng: Now at that time most of the people in Sāvatthī clung to sensual pleasures. Lustful, greedy, tied, infatuated, attached, and blinded, they lived completely addicted to sensual pleasures.

ud7.4:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
ud7.4:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

ud7.4:2.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā sāvatthiyā te manusse yebhuyyena kāmesu satte ratte giddhe gathite mucchite ajjhopanne andhīkate sammattakajāte kāmesu viharante.
ud7.4:2.2.eng: He saw how attached the humans were.

ud7.4:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud7.4:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud7.4:4.1.eng: “Blinded by sensual pleasures, wrapped in a net,

ud7.4:4.2.eng: they are smothered over by craving;

ud7.4:4.3.eng: bound by the kinsman of the negligent,

ud7.4:4.4.eng: like a fish caught in a funnel-net trap.

ud7.4:4.5.eng: They chase old age and death,

ud7.4:4.6.eng: like a suckling calf its mother.”

ud7.5:0.2.eng: Another Discourse with Bhaddiya the Dwarf

ud7.5:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud7.5:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud7.5:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā lakuṇḍakabhaddiyo sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
ud7.5:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Bhaddiya the Dwarf, closely following several mendicants, approached the Buddha.

ud7.5:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ lakuṇḍakabhaddiyaṃ dūratova sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito āgacchantaṃ dubbaṇṇaṃ duddasikaṃ okoṭimakaṃ yebhuyyena bhikkhūnaṃ paribhūtarūpaṃ.
ud7.5:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw Venerable Bhaddiya coming off in the distance—ugly, unsightly, deformed, and despised by most of the mendicants.

ud7.5:3.1.pli: “Passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, etaṃ bhikkhuṃ dūratova sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito āgacchantaṃ dubbaṇṇaṃ duddasikaṃ okoṭimakaṃ yebhuyyena bhikkhūnaṃ paribhūtarūpan”ti?
ud7.5:3.1.eng: “Mendicants, do you see this monk coming—ugly, unsightly, deformed, and despised by most of the mendicants?”

ud7.5:4.1.pli: “Eso, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mahiddhiko mahānubhāvo. Na ca sā samāpatti sulabharūpā yā tena bhikkhunā asamāpannapubbā.
ud7.5:4.1.eng: “That mendicant is very mighty and powerful. It’s not easy to find an attainment that he has not already attained.

ud7.5:4.2.pli: Yassa catthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.
ud7.5:4.2.eng: And he has realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lives having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

ud7.5:5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud7.5:5.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud7.6:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud7.6:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud7.6:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā aññāsikoṇḍañño bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṃ paccavekkhamāno.
ud7.6:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Koṇḍañña Who Understood was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight, reviewing the freedom through the ending of craving.

ud7.6:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ aññāsikoṇḍaññaṃ avidūre nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṃ paccavekkhamānaṃ.
ud7.6:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw him meditating there.

ud7.6:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud7.6:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud7.6:4.1.eng: “There is no root or ground or leaves for them,

ud7.6:4.2.eng: so where would creepers sprout from?

ud7.6:4.3.eng: That attentive one is released from bonds:

ud7.6:4.4.eng: who is worthy to criticize them?

ud7.6:4.6.eng: and by the Divinity, too, they’re praised.”

ud7.7:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud7.7:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud7.7:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā attano papañcasaññāsaṅkhāpahānaṃ paccavekkhamāno nisinno hoti.
ud7.7:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting reviewing his own giving up of the judgments driven by the proliferation of perceptions.
ud7.7:1.3.comm: “Judgment” (saṅkhā) refers to the way we “appraise” or “assess” ourselves, especially in relation to others (cf. MN 1:3.3, DN 1:1.3.2). | “Proliferation” (papañca) is the compulsion of the mind to spread out in endless inner commentary that hides reality. | “Perceptions” refer to the underlying tendencies that cause us to interpret the present in terms of the past. See MN 18 for a detailed explanation.

ud7.7:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā attano papañcasaññāsaṅkhāpahānaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud7.7:2.1.eng: Then, understanding his own giving up of the judgments driven by the proliferation of perceptions, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud7.7:3.1.eng: “There is no proliferation remaining in those

ud7.7:3.2.eng: who have passed beyond the halter and cross-bar.

ud7.7:3.3.eng: The sage who lives without craving

ud7.7:3.4.eng: is never scorned by the world with its gods.”

ud7.8:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud7.8:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud7.8:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahākaccāno bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya kāyagatāya satiyā ajjhattaṃ parimukhaṃ sūpaṭṭhitāya.
ud7.8:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Mahākaccāna was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight and mindfulness of the body well-established internally in his presence.

ud7.8:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ mahākaccānaṃ avidūre nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya kāyagatāya satiyā ajjhattaṃ parimukhaṃ sūpaṭṭhitāya.
ud7.8:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw him meditating there.

ud7.8:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud7.8:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud7.8:4.2.eng: be established in the body, constant:

ud7.8:4.3.pli: No cassa no ca me siyā,
ud7.8:4.3.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine,

ud7.8:4.4.pli: Na bhavissati na ca me bhavissati;
ud7.8:4.4.eng: It will not be, and it will not be mine.’

ud7.8:4.5.eng: Meditating stage by stage on that,

ud7.8:4.6.eng: in time they’d cross over clinging.”

ud7.9:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā mallesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena thūṇaṃ nāma mallānaṃ brāhmaṇagāmo tadavasari.
ud7.9:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Mallas together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a brahmin town of the Mallas named Thūṇa.

ud7.9:1.3.eng: The brahmins and householders of Thūṇa heard:

ud7.9:1.4.pli: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito mallesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ thūṇaṃ anuppatto”ti.
ud7.9:1.4.eng: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—while wandering in the land of the Mallas has arrived at Thūṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.”

ud7.9:1.5.pli: (…) Udapānaṃ tiṇassa ca bhusassa ca yāva mukhato pūresuṃ:
ud7.9:1.5.eng: They filled the well with grass and hay right to the top, thinking,

ud7.9:1.6.eng: “Don’t let these shavelings, these fake ascetics drink the water.”

ud7.9:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā maggā okkamma yena rukkhamūlaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
ud7.9:2.1.eng: And then the Buddha left the road, went to the root of a tree, and sat down on the seat spread out.

ud7.9:2.2.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
ud7.9:2.2.eng: When he was seated he said to Venerable Ānanda:

ud7.9:2.3.pli: “iṅgha me tvaṃ, ānanda, etamhā udapānā pānīyaṃ āharā”ti.
ud7.9:2.3.eng: “Please, Ānanda, fetch me some water from that well.”

ud7.9:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud7.9:3.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

ud7.9:3.2.pli: “idāni so, bhante, udapāno thūṇeyyakehi brāhmaṇagahapatikehi tiṇassa ca bhusassa ca yāva mukhato pūrito:
ud7.9:3.2.eng: “Just now, sir, the brahimns and householders of Thūṇa filled the well with grass and hay right to the top, thinking,

ud7.9:3.3.eng: ‘Don’t let these shavelings, these fake ascetics drink the water.’”

ud7.9:4.2.pli: tatiyampi kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
ud7.9:4.2.eng: and for a third time, the Buddha said to Ānanda:

ud7.9:4.3.pli: “iṅgha me tvaṃ, ānanda, etamhā udapānā pānīyaṃ āharā”ti.
ud7.9:4.3.eng: “Please, Ānanda, fetch me some water from that well.”

ud7.9:4.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā pattaṃ gahetvā yena so udapāno tenupasaṅkami.
ud7.9:4.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. Taking his bowl he went to the well.

ud7.9:4.5.pli: Atha kho so udapāno āyasmante ānande upasaṅkamante sabbaṃ taṃ tiṇañca bhusañca mukhato ovamitvā acchassa udakassa anāvilassa vippasannassa yāva mukhato pūrito vissandanto maññe aṭṭhāsi.
ud7.9:4.5.eng: As he approached the well, all the grass and hay erupted out of the well-mouth. The water stood transparent, unclouded, and clear right up to the top, seeming to overflow.

ud7.9:5.2.pli: “acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā.
ud7.9:5.2.eng: “Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might!

ud7.9:5.3.pli: Ayañhi so udapāno mayi upasaṅkamante sabbaṃ taṃ tiṇañca bhusañca mukhato ovamitvā acchassa udakassa anāvilassa vippasannassa yāva mukhato pūrito vissandanto maññe ṭhito”ti.
ud7.9:5.3.eng: For when I approached this well, all the grass and hay erupted out of the well-mouth. The water stood transparent, unclouded, and clear right up to the top, seeming to overflow.”

ud7.9:5.4.pli: Pattena pānīyaṃ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud7.9:5.4.eng: Gathering a bowl of drinking water he went back to the Buddha, and said to him,

ud7.9:5.5.pli: “acchariyaṃ, bhante, abbhutaṃ, bhante, tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā.
ud7.9:5.5.eng: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might!

ud7.9:5.6.pli: Ayañhi so, bhante, udapāno mayi upasaṅkamante sabbaṃ taṃ tiṇañca bhusañca mukhato ovamitvā acchassa udakassa anāvilassa vippasannassa yāva mukhato pūrito vissandanto maññe aṭṭhāsi.
ud7.9:5.6.eng: For when I approached that well, all the grass and hay erupted out of the well-mouth. The water stood transparent, unclouded, and clear right up to the top, seeming to overflow.

ud7.9:5.7.pli: Pivatu bhagavā pānīyaṃ, pivatu sugato pānīyan”ti.
ud7.9:5.7.eng: Drink the water, Blessed One! Drink the water, Holy One!”

ud7.9:6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud7.9:6.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud7.9:7.2.eng: if water is there all the time?

ud7.9:7.3.eng: Having cut off craving at the root,

ud7.9:7.4.eng: who would go out on a quest?”

ud8.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud8.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud8.1:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhū nibbānapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
ud8.1:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.

ud8.1:1.4.pli: Tedha bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbaṃ cetaso samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
ud8.1:1.4.eng: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

ud8.1:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud8.1:2.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud8.1:3.1.pli: “Atthi, bhikkhave, tadāyatanaṃ, yattha neva pathavī, na āpo, na tejo, na vāyo, na ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ, na viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ, na ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ, nāyaṃ loko, na paraloko, na ubho candimasūriyā.
ud8.1:3.1.eng: “There is, mendicants, that dimension where there is no earth, no water, no fire, no wind; no dimension of infinite space, no dimension of infinite consciousness, no dimension of nothingness, no dimension of neither perception nor non-perception; no this world, no other world, no moon or sun.

ud8.1:3.2.pli: Tatrāpāhaṃ, bhikkhave, neva āgatiṃ vadāmi, na gatiṃ, na ṭhitiṃ, na cutiṃ, na upapattiṃ;
ud8.1:3.2.eng: There, mendicants, I say there is no coming or going or remaining or passing away or reappearing.

ud8.1:3.3.eng: It is not established, does not proceed, and has no support.

ud8.1:3.4.eng: Just this is the end of suffering.”

ud8.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud8.10:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud8.10:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

ud8.10:2.1.pli: “Dabbassa, bhikkhave, mallaputtassa vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīditvā tejodhātuṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbutassa sarīrassa jhāyamānassa ḍayhamānassa neva chārikā paññāyittha na masi.
ud8.10:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, when Dabba the Mallian rose into the air and, sitting cross-legged in midair, entered and withdrew from the fire element before becoming fully quenched, his body burning and combusting left neither ashes nor soot to be found.

ud8.10:2.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma sappissa vā telassa vā jhāyamānassa ḍayhamānassa neva chārikā paññāyati na masi;
ud8.10:2.2.eng: It’s like when ghee or oil blaze and burn, and neither ashes nor soot are found.

ud8.10:2.3.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dabbassa mallaputtassa vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīditvā tejodhātuṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbutassa sarīrassa jhāyamānassa ḍayhamānassa neva chārikā paññāyittha na masī”ti.
ud8.10:2.3.eng: In the same way, when Dabba the Mallian rose into the air and, sitting cross-legged in midair, entered and withdrew from the fire element before becoming fully quenched, his body burning and combusting left neither ashes nor soot to be found.”

ud8.10:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud8.10:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud8.10:4.1.eng: “Just as the glow of iron struck

ud8.10:4.2.eng: by a hammer in the fire of Jātaveda

ud8.10:5.1.eng: in the same way, for the rightly released,

ud8.10:5.2.eng: who have crossed the flood of sensual bonds,

ud8.2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud8.2:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud8.2:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhū nibbānapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
ud8.2:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.

ud8.2:1.4.pli: Tedha bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbaṃ cetaso samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
ud8.2:1.4.eng: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

ud8.2:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud8.2:2.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud8.2:3.1.eng: “It’s hard to see what they call the ‘uninclined’,

ud8.2:3.2.eng: for the truth is not easy to see.

ud8.2:3.3.eng: For one who has penetrated craving,

ud8.2:3.4.eng: who knows and sees, there is nothing.”

ud8.3:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud8.3:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud8.3:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhū nibbānapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
ud8.3:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.

ud8.3:1.4.pli: Tedha bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā, manasi katvā, sabbaṃ cetaso samannāharitvā, ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
ud8.3:1.4.eng: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

ud8.3:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud8.3:2.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud8.3:3.1.eng: “There is, mendicants, that which is free of rebirth, free of what has been produced, made, and conditioned.

ud8.3:3.2.pli: No cetaṃ, bhikkhave, abhavissa ajātaṃ abhūtaṃ akataṃ asaṅkhataṃ, nayidha jātassa bhūtassa katassa saṅkhatassa nissaraṇaṃ paññāyetha.
ud8.3:3.2.eng: If there were nothing free of rebirth, free of what has been produced, made, and conditioned, then you would find no escape here from rebirth, from what has been produced, made, and conditioned.

ud8.3:3.3.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi ajātaṃ abhūtaṃ akataṃ asaṅkhataṃ, tasmā jātassa bhūtassa katassa saṅkhatassa nissaraṇaṃ paññāyatī”ti.
ud8.3:3.3.eng: But since there is that which is free of rebirth, free of what has been produced, made, and conditioned, an escape is found from rebirth, from what has been produced, made, and conditioned.”

ud8.4:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud8.4:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud8.4:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhū nibbānapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
ud8.4:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.

ud8.4:1.4.pli: Tedha bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbaṃ cetaso samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
ud8.4:1.4.eng: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

ud8.4:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud8.4:2.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud8.4:3.1.eng: “For the dependent there is agitation. For the independent there’s no agitation.
ud8.4:3.1.comm: This passage is quoted at MN 144:11.3 and SN 35.87:11.3, and referred to at Snp 3.12:44.3.

ud8.4:3.2.eng: When there’s no agitation there is tranquility.

ud8.4:3.3.eng: When there is tranquility there’s no inclination.

ud8.4:3.4.eng: When there’s no inclination, there’s no coming and going.

ud8.4:3.5.eng: When there’s no coming and going, there’s no passing away and reappearing.

ud8.4:3.6.pli: Cutūpapāte asati nevidha na huraṃ na ubhayamantarena.
ud8.4:3.6.eng: When there’s no passing away and reappearing there’s no this life or the next or between the two.

ud8.4:3.7.eng: Just this is the end of suffering.”
